12-40.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson are at the breakfast table where Holmes deduces information about their visitor from a left behind walking stick.
Holmes takes the walking stick to the window to examine it more closely with a convex lens, making further deductions about their visitor.
text_phrases: carrying the cane to the window
looked over it again with a convex lens
returned to his favourite corner of the settee

41-68.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Discuss Dr. Mortimer
41-68.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson discuss the details of Dr. James Mortimer's career and characteristics in their living room, while Holmes smokes and makes deductions.
text_phrases: Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his settee
blew little wavering rings of smoke up to the ceiling
Medical Directory and turned up the name

41-68.description: Sherlock Holmes deduces the breed of the dog by examining the teeth marks on the stick and then confirms his deduction as he sees the dog and its owner arriving.
text_phrases: Being a heavy stick the dog has held it tightly by the middle
marks of his teeth are very plainly visible

41-68.description: Dr. James Mortimer arrives at Sherlock Holmes's residence, surprising both Holmes and Watson with his appearance and demeanor.

69-90.scene_title: Holmes and Dr. Mortimer Discuss the Manuscript
69-90.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. James Mortimer are in a room discussing a manuscript related to the Baskerville family. Holmes analyzes the manuscript while Dr. Mortimer explains its significance and the tragic death of Sir Charles Baskerville.
text_phrases: I have in my pocket a manuscript
Holmes stretched out his hand for the manuscript and flattened it upon his knee
the yellow paper and the faded script

69-90.scene_title: The Legend of the Hound of the Baskervilles
69-90.description: Dr. Mortimer reads aloud a curious old-world narrative from the manuscript detailing the origin of the Hound of the Baskervilles, a legend within the Baskerville family, involving Hugo Baskerville and a tragic incident during the time of the Great Rebellion.
text_phrases: Dr. Mortimer turned the manuscript to the light and read
Of the origin of the Hound of the Baskervilles

69-90.description: The narrative describes a dark night when Hugo Baskerville, after a long carouse with his friends, abducts the daughter of a yeoman and the subsequent events leading to a curse on the Baskerville family.
text_phrases: Hugo and his friends sat down to a long carouse
the maiden was placed in an upper chamber
the growth of ivy which covered the south wall
flagons and trenchers flying before him

91-103.description: A group of revellers, after a sudden uproar, ride out into the moonlit moorlands in pursuit of a maid and encounter supernatural horrors.
text_phrases: took horse and started in pursuit
passed one of the night shepherds
Hugo Baskerville passed me upon his black mare
the black mare, dabbled with white froth
the unhappy maid where she had fallen
black beast, shaped like a hound

91-103.scene_title: Dr. Mortimer and Sherlock Holmes Discuss the Baskerville Curse
91-103.description: Dr. Mortimer reads a narrative about the Baskerville curse to Sherlock Holmes, who reacts skeptically.
text_phrases: pushed his spectacles up on his forehead
tossed the end of his cigarette into the fire

91-103.scene_title: The Death of Sir Charles Baskerville
91-103.description: Dr. Mortimer reads a newspaper account detailing the sudden and mysterious death of Sir Charles Baskerville, a well-loved local figure.
text_phrases: The recent sudden death of Sir Charles Baskerville
cast a gloom over the county
Sir Charles had resided at Baskerville Hall
his amiability of character and extreme generosity
made large sums of money in South African speculation
generous donations to local and county charities

104-112.scene_title: The Last Walk of Sir Charles Baskerville
104-112.description: Sir Charles Baskerville takes his habitual nocturnal walk down the yew alley of Baskerville Hall, but never returns. His footprints show he stood by the moor gate before proceeding down the alley where his body was later discovered.
text_phrases: walking down the famous yew alley of Baskerville Hall
gate which leads out on to the moor

104-112.description: Barrymore, the butler, alarmed by the open hall door and the absence of Sir Charles, lights a lantern and searches for his master down the yew alley, discovering unsettling changes in the footprints.
text_phrases: Barrymore, finding the hall door still open, became alarmed
went in search of his master
Sir Charles’s footprints altered their character

104-112.scene_title: Dr. Mortimer and Sherlock Holmes Discuss the Case
104-112.description: Dr. Mortimer meets with Sherlock Holmes to discuss the mysterious circumstances surrounding the death of Sir Charles Baskerville, revealing public and private facts about the case.
text_phrases: Dr. Mortimer refolded his paper and replaced it in his pocket
calling my attention to a case

113-152.scene_title: Sir Charles's Horror at the Hall Door
113-152.description: Dr. Mortimer recalls arriving at Sir Charles's residence and witnessing Sir Charles's terrified reaction to something he sees over Dr. Mortimer's shoulder, which turns out to be a large black calf.
text_phrases: driving up to his house in the evening
eyes fix themselves over my shoulder
expression of the most dreadful horror
large black calf passing at the head of the drive

113-152.scene_title: The Night of Sir Charles's Death
113-152.description: Dr. Mortimer describes the night he was summoned to Baskerville Hall after Sir Charles's death, detailing his observations of the scene and the mysterious footprints he discovered.
113-152.location: Baskerville Hall, Yew Alley, and Moor-gate
text_phrases: reach Baskerville Hall within an hour of the event
followed the footsteps down the yew alley
saw the spot at the moor-gate

153-197.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Mortimer discuss the mysterious circumstances surrounding Sir Charles's death near the moor-gate, focusing on the closed wicket-gate and the lack of significant marks around it.
text_phrases: same side of the path as the moor-gate
ash had twice dropped from his cigar
own marks all over that small patch of gravel

153-197.description: Sherlock Holmes expresses frustration over not being called to the scene earlier and discusses the supernatural elements of the case with Dr. Mortimer.
text_phrases: realm in which the most acute and most experienced of detectives is helpless
huge creature, luminous, ghastly, and spectral

153-197.description: Dr. Mortimer seeks advice from Sherlock Holmes about what to do with Sir Henry Baskerville, the heir to the Baskerville estate, considering the curse and the dangers of the moor.
text_phrases: Sir Henry Baskerville, who arrives at Waterloo Station
every Baskerville who goes there meets with an evil fate
prosperity of the whole poor, bleak countryside depends upon his presence

198-237.description: Dr. Mortimer visits Sherlock Holmes to discuss the safety of Sir Henry Baskerville, leading to a discussion about supernatural theories and practical advice.
198-237.location: Sherlock Holmes' residence, Baker Street, London
text_phrases: spaniel who is scratching at my front door
scribbled the appointment on his shirt-cuff

198-237.description: Holmes remains in his armchair, surrounded by smoke and papers, deeply engrossed in solving the case through intense mental concentration.
198-237.location: Sherlock Holmes' residence, Baker Street, London
text_phrases: acrid fumes of strong coarse tobacco
black clay pipe between his lips
rolls of paper lay around him
light of the lamp upon the table was blurred

198-237.description: Holmes, still in his armchair, examines a large-scale map of Devonshire, pointing out key locations relevant to the Baskerville case.
198-237.location: Sherlock Holmes' residence, Baker Street, London

238-272.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Discuss the Case
238-272.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson discuss the supernatural elements and logical explanations of their current investigation in a closed, concentrated environment.
text_phrases: I think we’ll shut that window again
Might I ask you to hand me my violin

238-272.scene_title: Meeting with Sir Henry and Dr. Mortimer
238-272.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson meet with Sir Henry Baskerville and Dr. Mortimer to discuss the mysterious events surrounding the Baskerville estate.
text_phrases: Our breakfast table was cleared early
He laid an envelope upon the table

273-302.scene_title: The Analysis of the Cut-Out Message
273-302.description: Sherlock Holmes, Dr. Mortimer, and Sir Henry Baskerville are in a room discussing a mysterious message that was cut out from a newspaper. Holmes explains how he deduced the source of the message and the implications of its content.
text_phrases: What do you make of it, Dr. Mortimer?
running his eyes up and down the columns
Capital article this on free trade
the words were from a newspaper
the cutter had to take two snips over ‘keep away.’

303-336.description: Dr. Mortimer and Sherlock Holmes analyze a problematic letter, discussing its origin and the issues with the pen and ink used, suggesting it was written in a hotel.
text_phrases: address has been written in a hotel
ink have given the writer trouble

303-336.description: Sir Henry discusses with Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Mortimer about his missing boot, an incident he finds peculiar and out of the ordinary.
text_phrases: put them both outside my door

303-336.description: Sir Henry listens intently as Dr. Mortimer recounts the details of the Baskerville inheritance and the mysterious circumstances surrounding it.
text_phrases: hound ever since I was in the nursery
case for a policeman or a clergyman

337-367.description: In a heated conversation, Baskerville expresses his unwavering decision to return to his ancestral home despite warnings of danger, both supernatural and human.
text_phrases: face flushed to a dusky red

337-367.description: Holmes and Watson hastily follow Dr. Mortimer and Baskerville through the streets of London, trying to keep a discreet distance. They witness a mysterious man in a cab who quickly evades them.
text_phrases: cab flew madly off down Regent Street

368-405.scene_title: Conversation and Plan on Regent Street
368-405.description: Sherlock Holmes and Watson discuss their next steps while walking down Regent Street, deciding not to follow Dr. Mortimer and his companion.
text_phrases: could swear only to the beard

368-405.description: Holmes and Watson enter a district messenger office where Holmes is recognized and initiates a new investigation with the help of a young lad named Cartwright.

368-405.scene_title: Artistic Interlude at Bond Street Gallery
368-405.description: Holmes and Watson visit a Bond Street picture gallery, where Holmes immerses himself in the art of modern Belgian masters, detaching from the case momentarily.
text_phrases: pictures of the modern Belgian masters

368-405.description: Holmes and Watson arrive at the Northumberland Hotel, where they encounter Sir Henry Baskerville in a state of anger over a missing boot.

406-456.description: A conversation about a missing boot between a guest and a German waiter in a hotel.

406-456.scene_title: Planning to Leave for Baskerville Hall
406-456.description: Holmes and Baskerville discuss plans to travel to Baskerville Hall, and the potential dangers in London.
Holmes, Baskerville, and Dr. Mortimer discuss the whereabouts of Barrymore and his potential involvement in suspicious activities.
Holmes, Baskerville, and Dr. Mortimer discuss the details of Sir Charles's will and the implications for the inheritors.
text_phrases: seven hundred and forty thousand pounds

457-492.description: Sir Henry and Mr. Holmes discuss the inheritance of the Baskerville estate and the associated responsibilities.
text_phrases: money should go with the title and estate

457-492.description: Holmes advises Sir Henry not to travel alone to Devonshire, suggesting he needs a trusty man by his side.
text_phrases: trusty man, who will be always by your side

457-492.description: Baskerville finds his missing boot hidden in the room, adding to the series of small mysteries.
text_phrases: drew a brown boot from under a cabinet

457-492.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Discuss the Case
457-492.description: Holmes and Watson discuss the complexities of the case while receiving telegrams with updates.
A cabman arrives at Holmes' office, confronting him about the inquiries made.
text_phrases: I got a message from the head office

493-534.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson are in a room where Holmes is questioning a cabman named John Clayton about his recent fare who claimed to be a detective and followed two gentlemen.
text_phrases: Sherlock Holmes made a note of it

493-534.description: John Clayton recounts his day following two gentlemen on the instructions of a man claiming to be Sherlock Holmes, starting from Trafalgar Square to various locations, ending at Waterloo Station.
text_phrases: He hailed me at half-past nine in Trafalgar Square
drove down to the Northumberland Hotel
followed their cab until it pulled up somewhere near here
drove right away to Waterloo Station

493-534.scene_title: Holmes and Watson's Departure to Devonshire
493-534.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson prepare to leave for Devonshire, discussing the case and their concerns about the dangers involved.
text_phrases: we started as arranged for Devonshire
Mr. Sherlock Holmes drove with me to the station
his last parting injunctions and advice

535-558.description: Holmes and Watson discuss the list of suspects involved in their current case, considering the implications of dismissing or keeping each suspect under observation.
text_phrases: get rid of this Barrymore couple
preserve them upon our list of suspects
there is a groom at the Hall

535-558.description: Holmes, Watson, and Sir Henry Baskerville prepare to depart by train, discussing precautions and the mysterious loss of a boot.
text_phrases: Keep your revolver near you night and day
the train began to glide down the platform
avoid the moor in those hours of darkness

535-558.description: During the train journey, the characters discuss their past and the significance of returning to Devon, while observing the changing landscape.
text_phrases: the brown earth had become ruddy
red cows grazed in well-hedged fields
the familiar features of the Devon scenery

535-558.description: The group arrives at a small station, greeted by the station-master and porters, and observes the moor's ominous presence as they set off in a wagonette.
text_phrases: the train pulled up at a small wayside station
a wagonette with a pair of cobs was waiting
station-master and porters clustered round us
the long, gloomy curve of the moor

559-578.description: The wagonette travels through deep lanes, over a granite bridge, and alongside a noisy stream, surrounded by a lush countryside as the sun sets.
text_phrases: wagonette swung round into a side road
deep lanes worn by centuries of wheels
noisy stream which gushed swiftly down

559-578.description: The travelers encounter a stern, mounted soldier watching the road, informed about an escaped convict.
text_phrases: rifle poised ready over his forearm

559-578.description: The wagonette arrives at Baskerville Hall, passing through the lodge gates into a sombre avenue leading up to the foreboding manor.
text_phrases: lodge-gates, a maze of fantastic tracery in wrought iron
old trees shot their branches in a sombre tunnel

579-601.description: A tall man and a woman silhouette against the hall light as they help hand down bags from the wagonette. Dr. Mortimer and Sir Henry discuss dinner plans briefly before Dr. Mortimer departs.
text_phrases: tall man had stepped from the shadow of the porch
figure of a woman was silhouetted against the yellow light of the hall
open the door of the wagonette

579-601.description: Sir Henry and the narrator enter the grand hall of Baskerville Hall, observing its old-fashioned, somber decor and warming themselves by the log-fire.
text_phrases: large, lofty, and heavily raftered with huge baulks of age-blackened oak
high, thin window of old stained glass

579-601.description: Sir Henry and the narrator dine in a shadowy, long chamber of Baskerville Hall, feeling subdued by the somber atmosphere and the silent company of ancestors' portraits.
text_phrases: long chamber with a step separating the dais
black beams shot across above our heads

579-601.description: The narrator draws aside the curtains to look out at the grassy space in front of Baskerville Hall, observing the moody landscape under a half moon.
text_phrases: grassy space which lay in front of the hall door
two copses of trees moaned and swung
half moon broke through the rifts of racing clouds
long, low curve of the melancholy moor

602-622.description: The protagonist is unable to sleep and hears the sob of a woman in the dead of night, stirring him to alertness in his room.
text_phrases: tossing restlessly from side to side
chiming clock struck out the quarters of the hours

602-622.description: Sir Henry and the narrator discuss their eerie experience from the night before while having breakfast in a sunlit room.
text_phrases: sunlight flooded in through the high mullioned windows
watery patches of colour from the coats of arms

602-622.description: Sir Henry and the narrator confront Barrymore about the nocturnal sobbing, leading to a tense exchange.
The narrator encounters Mrs. Barrymore in the corridor, noticing her distressed appearance which contradicts her husband's earlier statements.
text_phrases: met Mrs. Barrymore in the long corridor

602-622.description: The narrator visits the postmaster to verify the delivery of a crucial telegram, uncovering more about Barrymore's whereabouts.
602-622.location: Post Office in a small grey hamlet

623-652.description: Dr. Watson is surprised by a stranger, Mr. Stapleton, who introduces himself on the moor. Stapleton, carrying a butterfly-net and a tin box, discusses local legends and expresses interest in Sherlock Holmes.
Stapleton and Watson walk along a moor path discussing the local area and Stapleton invites Watson to meet his sister at Merripit House.
623-652.location: Moor path leading to Merripit House
text_phrases: narrow grassy path struck off from the road
undulating downs, long green rollers, with crests of jagged granite

653-690.description: Stapleton and the narrator discuss the dangerous terrain of the Grimpen Mire on the moor, where a misstep can be fatal. Stapleton reveals his knowledge of safe paths through the mire.
A mysterious and eerie moan sweeps over the moor, which Stapleton attributes to natural causes, while the narrator is chilled with fear.
Stapleton shows the narrator the remains of prehistoric settlements on the moor, explaining their history and significance.
Stapleton suddenly chases after a moth with great energy, demonstrating his agility and deep interest in the natural elements of the moor.
653-690.location: The moor near the great mire

691-716.description: Dr. Watson meets Miss Stapleton on a lonely moorland path. She is strikingly beautiful and contrasts sharply with her brother, Stapleton. She urgently warns Dr. Watson to leave the moor and return to London for his own safety.
Miss Stapleton warns Dr. Watson with urgency and mystery, insisting he should leave the moor immediately. Her brother, Stapleton, joins them, and the tension between the siblings is palpable.
Dr. Watson, along with the Stapleton siblings, arrives at Merripit House, a bleak and melancholy dwelling on the moor, surrounded by a stunted orchard.

717-738.scene_title: Dr. Watson's Refusal to Stay for Lunch
717-738.description: Dr. Watson resists the invitation to stay for lunch, eager to return to his duties amidst the melancholy of the moor and the recent events.
text_phrases: eager to get back to my charge

717-738.description: Dr. Watson encounters Miss Stapleton, who has hurriedly run to intercept him, expressing regret over a previous misunderstanding and warning him about the dangers of the moor.
text_phrases: Miss Stapleton sitting upon a rock

717-738.description: Miss Stapleton warns Dr. Watson about the dangers associated with the Baskerville curse and urges him to convince Sir Henry to leave the moor.
text_phrases: the curse which hung over the family

717-738.scene_title: Dr. Watson's Reflections on the Moor
717-738.description: Dr. Watson reflects on the spirit of the moor, its vastness, and the remnants of prehistoric people, feeling a deep connection to the ancient land.
text_phrases: spirit of the moor sink into one’s soul

739-745.description: Sir Henry, Stapleton, and the narrator take an excursion across the moor to the site of the legend of wicked Hugo, discussing supernatural influences and observing the eerie landscape.
text_phrases: excursion of some miles across the moor
open, grassy space flecked over with the white cotton grass
two great stones, worn and sharpened at the upper end

739-745.description: After the moor excursion, Sir Henry, Stapleton, the narrator, and Miss Stapleton have lunch at Merripit House where Sir Henry and Miss Stapleton's mutual attraction becomes evident.
text_phrases: stayed for lunch at Merripit House
Sir Henry made the acquaintance of Miss Stapleton

746-760.description: Dr. Mortimer, having excavated a prehistoric skull, shares his findings during a lunch at Sir Henry's residence.
text_phrases: prehistoric skull which fills him with great joy

746-760.description: Dr. Mortimer takes the group to the yew alley to explain the events of the fatal night.
746-760.location: Yew Alley at Sir Henry's estate
text_phrases: between two high walls of clipped hedge
white wooden gate with a latch

746-760.description: The narrator observes Barrymore walking stealthily down the corridor with a candle, appearing guilty.
text_phrases: long black shadow was trailing down the corridor
man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand

761-775.description: The scene describes the protagonist observing Barrymore, who is crouching at a window in an unfurnished room at Baskerville Hall, holding a candle against the glass and looking out into the moor.
text_phrases: Barrymore was crouching at the window
stared out into the blackness of the moor

761-775.description: The protagonist revisits the room where Barrymore was seen the previous night to investigate the peculiarities of the western window that overlooks the moor.
text_phrases: examined the room in which Barrymore had been
western window through which he had stared so intently
commands the nearest outlook on to the moor

761-775.description: The protagonist discusses with Sir Henry the mysterious behavior of Barrymore and plans to shadow him to uncover his secretive activities.
761-775.location: Sir Henry's study at Baskerville Hall
text_phrases: had an interview with the baronet in his study after breakfast
told him all that I had seen

776-789.description: Sir Henry and Watson prepare to go out to the moor, discussing the importance of not going alone.
text_phrases: Sir Henry put on his hat

776-789.description: Watson observes Sir Henry and Miss Stapleton from a hill, debating his duty to follow them.
Stapleton interrupts Sir Henry and Miss Stapleton's conversation, leading to a heated exchange.
text_phrases: Sir Henry suddenly drew Miss Stapleton to his side

776-789.description: Watson meets Sir Henry at the bottom of the hill, explaining his actions and discussing the confrontation.
776-789.location: Base of the hill near Merripit House
text_phrases: met the baronet at the bottom

790-805.description: Sir Henry recounts his failed attempt to woo a woman on the prairie, being interrupted by her furious brother.
text_phrases: brother was well up to the front
running at us with a face on him like a madman

790-805.description: Stapleton visits Sir Henry to apologize for his earlier behavior, explaining his deep bond with his sister and his fear of losing her.
text_phrases: private interview with Sir Henry in his study
sister is everything in his life
thought of losing her was really terrible to him

806-824.description: Sir Henry and the narrator sit up late into the night, listening for any sounds in the quiet house, only to fall asleep in their chairs.
text_phrases: sat up with Sir Henry in his rooms
nearly three o'clock in the morning

806-824.description: On the second night, Sir Henry and the narrator lower the lamp and sit in silence, smoking cigarettes, until they hear a creak in the passage.
text_phrases: creak of a step in the passage

806-824.description: Sir Henry and the narrator stealthily follow the mysterious figure through the dark corridors until they see him crouching at the window.
806-824.location: Corridor and other wing of the house
text_phrases: stealthily we heard it pass along
candle framed it in the darkness

806-824.description: Barrymore is caught by Sir Henry and the narrator at the window, leading to a tense confrontation where Barrymore is questioned about his actions.
806-824.location: Room with the western lattice window
text_phrases: Barrymore sprang up from the window
holding a candle to the window
shadows sprang up and down from the shaking of his candle

806-824.description: The narrator takes the candle from Barrymore and discovers a signal response from across the moor, confirming their suspicions of a secret communication.
806-824.location: Room with the western lattice window
text_phrases: took the candle from the trembling hand of the butler
black square framed by the window

825-854.description: In a tense indoor scene, Sir Henry confronts the Barrymores about their secretive actions, leading to Mrs. Barrymore's emotional revelation about helping her escaped convict brother, Selden.
text_phrases: Mrs. Barrymore, paler and more horror-struck than her husband, was standing at the door
Her bulky figure in a shawl and skirt

825-854.description: After learning the truth about the light signals, Sir Henry and Watson decide to capture Selden, the escaped convict. They prepare for a night expedition on the moor.
text_phrases: Sir Henry had flung it open, and the cold night wind beat in upon our faces
Get your revolver and put on your boots

825-854.description: Sir Henry and Watson venture out into the moor at night, guided by the distant light, to capture Selden. The atmosphere is tense and eerie with the autumn wind and falling leaves.
text_phrases: We hurried through the dark shrubbery, amid the dull moaning of the autumn wind and the rustle of the falling leaves
The light still burned steadily in front

855-891.description: Watson and the baronet are on the moor at night when they hear the eerie and terrifying cry of the mythical Hound of the Baskervilles, which sends a chill through them.
text_phrases: out of the vast gloom of the moor
face glimmered white through the darkness

855-891.description: Watson and Sir Henry, while searching for a convict on the moor at night, encounter him by a signal light. The convict, surprised and threatened, attempts to escape.
text_phrases: guttering candle was stuck in a crevice of the rocks
boulder of granite concealed our approach
light beneath him was reflected in his small, cunning eyes

892-897.description: Two characters chase a figure across the moor under moonlight but fail to catch up, eventually stopping to rest on rocks. A mysterious figure appears on a granite tor, silhouetted against the moon, then disappears.
text_phrases: small speck moving swiftly among the boulders
jagged pinnacle of a granite tor
figure of a man upon the tor

892-897.description: The morning after the chase, the moor is enveloped in fog and drizzle, creating a melancholic and ominous atmosphere. The baronet is in a dark mood, reflecting on the sinister influences around them.
text_phrases: house is banked in with rolling clouds
thin, silver veins upon the sides of the hills

898-926.description: The protagonist reflects on the possibility that a mysterious stranger he saw on the moor could be following them, just as they were dogged in London.
text_phrases: stranger whom I saw upon the tor

898-926.description: Barrymore requests to speak with Sir Henry, leading to a heated discussion in the study about the pursuit of Barrymore's brother-in-law, Selden.
text_phrases: Barrymore asked leave to speak with Sir Henry

898-926.description: Barrymore pleads with Sir Henry not to inform the police about Selden's presence on the moor, fearing for his and his wife's safety.
text_phrases: Barrymore considers that he has a grievance
Barrymore standing very pale but very collected
beg you, sir, to say nothing to the police

898-926.description: Barrymore reveals to Sir Henry and Watson that he knows why Sir Charles was at the gate at the hour of his death, hinting at a meeting with a woman.
text_phrases: It’s about poor Sir Charles’s death
It was to meet a woman

927-950.description: Barrymore recounts to Sir Henry and Watson how his wife discovered the remains of a burned letter in Sir Charles's study, which could potentially be linked to his mysterious death.
text_phrases: found the ashes of a burned letter in the back of the grate
one little slip, the end of a page, hung together

927-950.description: Watson ventures out into the rainy moor, reflecting on the convict and the mysterious figure he previously saw, and later discusses the initials L.L. with Dr. Mortimer while returning in a dog-cart.
text_phrases: rain poured down, rustling on the ivy and dripping from the eaves
walked far upon the sodden moor
rain squalls drifted across their russet face

951-984.description: A conversation between the narrator and another character about the difficult life circumstances of Mrs. Laura Lyons, including her background, current situation, and the support she receives from the community.
text_phrases: old Frankland allows her a pittance
set her up in a typewriting business

951-984.description: The narrator discusses with Barrymore about a mysterious stranger on the moor, revealing tensions and fears related to the safety of Sir Henry and the dark activities happening around Baskerville Hall.
text_phrases: stone huts where the old folk used to live
lad who works for him and brings all he needs

985-1018.description: The narrator informs Sir Henry about the discoveries regarding Mrs. Laura Lyons during breakfast, discussing the potential visit to Coombe Tracey.
text_phrases: Dr. Mortimer remained with him at cards until it was very late
At breakfast, however, I informed him about my discovery

985-1018.description: The narrator arrives at Coombe Tracey, instructs Perkins to take care of the horses, and proceeds to find Mrs. Lyons' residence.
text_phrases: When I reached Coombe Tracey I told Perkins to put up the horses
I made inquiries for the lady whom I had come to interrogate

985-1018.description: The narrator meets Mrs. Lyons, who is initially welcoming but becomes guarded upon realizing he is a stranger. They discuss Sir Charles Baskerville.
text_phrases: A maid showed me in without ceremony
Mrs. Lyons was sitting before a Remington typewriter
Her face fell, however, when she saw that I was a stranger

985-1018.description: The narrator questions Mrs. Lyons about her correspondence and relationship with Sir Charles, leading to a tense exchange.
text_phrases: What can I tell you about him?
The object is to avoid a public scandal
I could even quote a passage of your letter

1019-1054.description: A tense and detailed interrogation scene where the protagonist questions Mrs. Lyons about her actions and intentions regarding Sir Charles, leading up to his death.

The protagonist reflects on the investigation while driving back across the moor, contemplating the vague directions and the challenge of locating the mysterious stranger in one of the many stone huts.

1055-1079.description: Dr. Watson encounters Mr. Frankland outside his garden, who invites him to celebrate his legal victories.
1055-1079.location: Outside Mr. Frankland's garden gate, highroad
text_phrases: outside the gate of his garden

1055-1079.description: Mr. Frankland explains his recent legal victories to Dr. Watson in his dining room.
text_phrases: right of way through the centre of old Middleton’s park

1055-1079.description: Mr. Frankland reveals to Dr. Watson that he has observed a child delivering food to the convict on the moor.
text_phrases: his food is taken to him by a child
I see him every day through my telescope
passes along the same path at the same hour

1055-1079.description: Mr. Frankland points out the landscape features to Dr. Watson, arguing against his suggestion about the shepherd's son.
text_phrases: low hill beyond with the thornbush upon it
stoniest part of the whole moor

1080-1095.description: Frankland and Dr. Watson use a telescope mounted on the flat leads of the house to observe a boy climbing a hill.
text_phrases: telescope, a formidable instrument mounted upon a tripod

1080-1095.description: Dr. Watson follows the boy over the moor and up the hill, observing the changing landscape and the setting sun.
text_phrases: stony hill over which the boy had disappeared
golden-green on one side and grey shadow on the other

1080-1095.description: Dr. Watson discovers a hut on the moor, which appears to be the hiding place of the mysterious man.
1080-1095.location: Moor, near a circle of old stone huts
text_phrases: circle of the old stone huts
dilapidated opening which served as a door
flat stone served the purpose of a table

1096-1124.description: The sun sets, casting a golden glow over Grimpen Mire, with distant views of Baskerville Hall and the village of Grimpen.
text_phrases: Outside the sun was sinking low
the west was blazing with scarlet and gold
distant pools which lay amid the great Grimpen Mire
distant blur of smoke which marked the village of Grimpen

1096-1124.description: Watson waits anxiously in a dark hut, hearing footsteps approaching as he prepares for a confrontation.
text_phrases: I sat in the dark recess of the hut
waited with sombre patience for the coming of its tenant
sharp clink of a boot striking upon a stone
I shrank back into the darkest corner
cocked the pistol in my pocket

1096-1124.description: Holmes surprises Watson by revealing himself outside the hut, easing Watson's tension and fear.
1096-1124.location: Outside the hut near Grimpen Mire
text_phrases: a shadow fell across the opening of the hut
It is a lovely evening, my dear Watson
he sat upon a stone outside
please be careful with the revolver

1096-1124.description: Holmes and Watson discuss recent events and revelations, sharing insights and confirming their parallel investigations.
1096-1124.location: Outside the hut near Grimpen Mire
text_phrases: I never was more glad to see anyone in my life
The surprise was not all on one side
Cartwright has brought up some supplies
you have been to Coombe Tracey, have you?

1125-1156.scene_title: Holmes and Watson in the Hut
1125-1156.description: Holmes and Watson discuss the case in the twilight inside a hut on the moor as the temperature drops outside.
text_phrases: dusk was settling over the moor
we withdrew into the hut for warmth
Holmes took a bundle of papers from his pocket

1125-1156.description: Holmes reveals to Watson the true identity of Miss Stapleton and discusses the implications of this discovery.
text_phrases: the lady who has passed here as Miss Stapleton is in reality his wife
Holmes took a bundle of papers

1125-1156.description: As night fully sets in, Holmes and Watson continue their discussion under the starlit sky, pondering over the villain's motives.
text_phrases: night had settled upon the moor
a few faint stars were gleaming in a violet sky

1157-1184.description: Holmes and Watson hear a terrible scream while discussing a murder case on the moor, prompting them to rush into the darkness to investigate.
text_phrases: dark, athletic outline at the door of the hut

1157-1184.description: Holmes and Watson find the body of Sir Henry Baskerville on the moor after following the sounds of his distress.
1157-1184.location: Moor near a ridge of rocks

1157-1184.description: Holmes and Watson, devastated by the death of Sir Henry, vow to avenge him while reflecting on the events that led to this tragedy.

1185-1222.scene_title: Discovery of the Body on the Moor
1185-1222.description: Holmes and Watson discover the body of Selden, mistaken for Sir Henry, on the moor under the moonlight. They examine the body, realizing the mix-up due to the clothes.
text_phrases: body, black and clear against the silvered stones
dripping beard was pointing up to the cold, clear moon

1185-1222.description: Stapleton approaches Holmes and Watson on the moor, surprised to see them with a body, initially mistaking it for Sir Henry.
text_phrases: dull red glow of a cigar
dapper shape and jaunty walk of the naturalist

1223-1254.description: Holmes and Watson discuss the case on the moor, reflecting on the challenges and the cunning of their adversary.
text_phrases: We’re at close grips at last
What a nerve the fellow has!

1223-1254.scene_title: Holmes and Watson's Return to Baskerville Hall
1223-1254.description: Holmes and Watson return to Baskerville Hall, discussing their plans and the lack of evidence in their case.
text_phrases: Holmes and I set off to Baskerville Hall
walked, lost in thought, as far as the Baskerville gates

1223-1254.description: Holmes and Watson arrive at Baskerville Hall, where they prepare to inform Sir Henry of recent developments over dinner.
text_phrases: over a belated supper we explained to the baronet
she wept bitterly in her apron

1255-1290.description: Sir Henry and Sherlock Holmes discuss the ongoing investigation and the peculiar events surrounding the Baskerville family, including the mysterious hound and the portraits in the hall.
text_phrases: the lamp beat upon his face
line of portraits which covered the opposite wall

1255-1290.description: Holmes examines a portrait of Hugo Baskerville, the ancestor believed to have started the curse of the Baskerville hound, and discusses its features and historical significance with Watson.
text_phrases: the time-stained portrait on the wall
broad plumed hat, the curling love-locks, the white lace collar
held it up against the portrait

1291-1334.description: Holmes and Watson discover that Stapleton's face resembles a portrait, leading Holmes to deduce his criminal intentions.
text_phrases: The face of Stapleton had sprung out of the canvas

1291-1334.description: Holmes is seen by Watson coming up the drive early in the morning, indicating his preparation for the day's investigative work.
Holmes and Watson discuss their plans with Sir Henry, including their imminent departure to London, leaving Sir Henry disappointed.
text_phrases: You look like a general who is planning a battle

1291-1334.description: Holmes and Watson make their arrangements to leave for London, bidding farewell to a disheartened Sir Henry.
text_phrases: we were at the station of Coombe Tracey

1335-1372.description: Holmes receives a telegram from Lestrade while discussing plans with Watson.
text_phrases: The boy returned with a telegram

1335-1372.description: Sherlock Holmes confronts Mrs. Laura Lyons in her office about her involvement in Sir Charles Baskerville's death.
text_phrases: Mrs. Laura Lyons was in her office
Her hands were grasping the arms of her chair
drawing several papers from his pocket

1335-1372.description: Holmes reveals the true identity of Mr. Stapleton to Mrs. Lyons, showing evidence of his deceit.
text_phrases: Here is a photograph of the couple
three written descriptions by trustworthy witnesses

1373-1399.description: Sherlock Holmes, Lestrade, and the narrator arrive at the station where Holmes disembarks from the London express.
text_phrases: The London express came roaring into the station
a small, wiry bulldog of a man had sprung from a first-class carriage

1373-1399.description: After disembarking, Holmes discusses the plan for the evening, including dinner and a trip to Dartmoor.
text_phrases: We have two hours before we need think of starting
giving you a breath of the pure night air of Dartmoor

1373-1399.description: Holmes, Lestrade, and the narrator travel in a wagonette through the dark towards Merripit House, discussing trivial matters due to the presence of the driver.
text_phrases: we at last passed Frankland’s house

1373-1399.description: Holmes, Lestrade, and the narrator set up an ambush near Merripit House, hiding behind rocks and observing the house in silence.
text_phrases: These rocks upon the right make an admirable screen

1373-1399.scene_title: Observation of Sir Henry and Stapleton
1373-1399.description: The narrator observes Sir Henry and Stapleton through a window at Merripit House, noting their actions and expressions.
text_phrases: I could look straight through the uncurtained window
Both of them were smoking cigars

1400-1414.description: A dense, white fog drifts towards Holmes and Watson, creating an eerie atmosphere as it blankets the moor and obscures the house in the distance.
1400-1414.location: Grimpen Mire, moor near the house

1400-1414.description: Holmes, Watson, and Lestrade encounter the monstrous hound as it emerges from the fog, leading to a terrifying chase and a deadly confrontation.
text_phrases: sharp click of a cocking pistol
fire burst from its open mouth

1415-1444.description: Sir Henry is found insensible and is revived by Holmes, Lestrade, and Watson. They discover a monstrous creature, dead, which they identify as the source of phosphorus.
text_phrases: Holmes breathed a prayer of gratitude
terrible creature which was lying stretched before us
huge jaws seemed to be dripping with a bluish flame

1415-1444.description: Holmes, Watson, and Lestrade break into a locked room in Baskerville Hall, expecting to find a villain but instead discover Mrs. Stapleton bound and mistreated.
text_phrases: Pistol in hand, we all three rushed into the room
figure was tied, so swathed and muffled in the sheets
Mrs. Stapleton sank upon the floor

1445-1459.scene_title: Holmes and the Old Tin Mine
1445-1459.description: Holmes and Watson learn from Mrs. Stapleton about the old tin mine where Stapleton kept his hound and made preparations for refuge. The scene is set against a backdrop of a foggy night, making it impossible to navigate the Grimpen Mire.
text_phrases: old tin mine on an island in the heart of the mire
fog-bank lay like white wool against the window
Holmes held the lamp towards it

1445-1459.description: After the death of the hound, Holmes, Watson, and Mrs. Stapleton navigate a perilous pathway through the bog, marked by small wands. The scene vividly describes the treacherous terrain and the remnants of Stapleton's flight.
text_phrases: small wand planted here and there
old black boot in the air

1445-1459.scene_title: The Abandoned Mine and the Hound's Hideout
1445-1459.description: Holmes and Watson discover the abandoned mine where Stapleton hid his savage hound. They find remnants of the miners' cottages and the confined area where the hound was kept, along with a skeleton of a dog.
1445-1459.location: Abandoned mine on the island in Grimpen Mire
text_phrases: huge driving-wheel and a shaft half-filled with rubbish
crumbling remains of the cottages of the miners
a staple and chain with a quantity of gnawed bones
skeleton with a tangle of brown hair

1460-1466.scene_title: A Foggy Evening at Baker Street
1460-1466.description: Holmes and Watson are seated by a blazing fire in their sitting room, discussing past cases and recent successes.
text_phrases: Holmes and I sat, upon a raw and foggy night
on either side of a blazing fire
in our sitting-room in Baker Street

1460-1466.description: Holmes recounts the events and intricacies of the Baskerville case to Watson, explaining the actions and motives of Stapleton.
text_phrases: Holmes discussing the details of the Baskerville mystery
from the point of view of the man who called himself Stapleton

1467-1472.description: Stapleton buys a savage hound and uses artificial means to make it appear diabolical. He hides it in Grimpen Mire and attempts to use it to kill Sir Charles by luring him outside at night.
text_phrases: artificial means to make the creature diabolical

1467-1472.description: Stapleton treats the hound with infernal paint and sets it on Sir Charles, who is waiting at the gate. The hound chases Sir Charles down the yew alley, causing him to die from heart disease and terror.
Stapleton manipulates Mrs. Laura Lyons by pretending to be single and promising marriage, using her to lure Sir Charles out for an interview, setting the stage for the fatal encounter with the hound.

1473-1480.description: Stapleton attempts to acquire Sir Henry's old boot to use for setting a hound on his track, indicating his meticulous planning and criminal intent.
text_phrases: Stapleton to get some article of Sir Henry’s attire
boots or chamber-maid of the hotel was well bribed
first boot which was procured for him was a new one

1473-1480.description: Discussion about Stapleton's past criminal activities and his clever escape tactics, revealing his dangerous and resourceful nature.
The old manservant Anthony, likely caring for the hound during Stapleton's absence, highlighting the secretive and calculated operations of Stapleton.
The narrator secretly watches Stapleton while staying at Coombe Tracey, using Cartwright's assistance to maintain surveillance.
text_phrases: stayed for the most part at Coombe Tracey
used the hut upon the moor

1481-1488.description: A dramatic scene where Mrs. Stapleton confronts her husband about his murderous plans, leading to a furious argument and her eventual restraint to prevent her from warning Sir Henry.
text_phrases: She taxed her husband with his intended crime

1481-1488.description: The scene on the moor where the true nature of the beast is revealed, and Stapleton's plans come to a disastrous end.
text_phrases: the death of the unfortunate convict
the terrible and paralyzing spectacle which the beast presented
the fog which enabled him to burst upon us

1481-1488.description: Stapleton and Mrs. Stapleton discuss various strategies for claiming the inheritance without arousing suspicion, highlighting Stapleton's cunning and desperation.
text_phrases: Mrs. Stapleton has heard her husband discuss the problem
He might claim the property from South America
establish his identity before the British authorities

1481-1488.description: Holmes and Watson prepare for a relaxing evening at the opera after solving the case, marking a return to normalcy and leisure.
text_phrases: we may turn our thoughts into more pleasant channels
I have a box for _Les Huguenots_
be ready in half an hour
stop at Marcini’s for a little dinner on the way
